H0.text: A cloud can be used to represent water cycling through the atmosphere in a drawing of the water cycle.

H1.text: A stream can be used to represent water cycling through the atmosphere in a student's drawing of the water cycle.

H2.text: A frozen lake is an image the student can use to represent water cycling through the atmosphere in a drawing of the water cycle.

H3.text: A drop of dew is an image a student can use to represent water cycling through the atmosphere in a drawing of the water cycle.

A4.text: Condensation: The transformation of water vapor to liquid water droplets in the air, creating clouds and fog.

A5.text: A portion of this runoff enters rivers, with streamflow moving water towards the oceans.

A6.text: Saturation occurs when the dew point is raised to the ambient air temperature.

A7.text: In a warmer climate, more water would enter the atmosphere by evaporation at the surface; as clouds are formed from water vapor, cloudiness would be expected to increase.

A8.text: The evaporation will continue until an equilibrium is reached when the evaporation of the liquid is equal to its condensation.

A9.text: Evaporation is an essential part of the water cycle.

A10.text: Formations due to condensation, such as clouds, haze, fog, and mist, are composed of hydrometeors.

A11.text: Large water bodies such as lakes efficiently store heat that results in significant temperature differences (larger than 13 °C or 23 °F) between the water surface and the air above.
